Newton's Inverse Square Law and Antigravity Newton's inverse square law for gravity works just as well in reverse for antigravity.  The force on both Earth and Moon from empty space, is anti gravity or dark matter. That antigravity force is the same everywhere with one exception.  That exception is the area between the Earth and Moon where the red arrow is.  That is where antigravity is weakest.  The empty space that pushes from all sides, pushes Earth and the Moon together. That antigravity from space is much stronger than the small anti gravity in between the Earth and Moon that barely keeps them apart.   The force of gravity from mass is really antigravity from empty space.

Force (physics) does not exist physically in the same way that an object with mass, thus making it “not” the initial cause of pushing, pulling, shaping objects, motion, work or being a Vector Quantity (Magnitude + Direction).  In physics, the word, “Force” as we know it, turns out to be nothing more than an expression to express an idea like one would use the word “Love” to express one's feelings.  But, physics and in mathematics, still use “Force” as thou it were something physical that could enable the initial cause of motion is wrong making it counterintuitive.   History teaches us that change is always constant.  Here is my challenge to anyone.  Without applying the Energy from within you, choose an object of your choices that is in front of you and try pushing and pulling it by simply applying “only” the Force or Net Force.  Remember, no energy.  Meaning that Energy (applied energy) is the origin of motion and not “Force”.  Once Energy (E) is applied, it creates what is known as Momentum (p).  When this Momentum (mass and velocity) comes in contact with another object(s), it makes a surface contact that will enable you to push and pull.  Example:  Ep=ma, Ep=mv and so on.  Note:  Ep is not to be confused as Kinetic Energy in any way.  Momentum represents things like work, wave, gravity, light, lightning, tsunami, earthquake, current, electricity, motion, magnetism, hurricane, etc.  Also note, that it’s “not” the size of a planet, but the amount of energy (E) being applied from within the planet that creates a strong or weak gravity.  Example:  A black hole the size of a marble can engulf or destroy our sun.   Without Energy, there is no Momentum.  Without Momentum, there is no surface contact on an object(s) to push, pull, work, shaping objects, motion, gravity, etc.  Momentum does not and cannot exist without the applied Energy that creates it.  Energy and Momentum or “Ep” is the only common denominator that links all fundamental forces of nature.  Without Ep, all fundamental forces of nature would be inert and non-existence.  Energy is energy, but it’s when Energy (E) is being applied that creates the Momentum (p) making it the initial cause of motion.  Example:  Ep. By applying the right amount of Energy, nothing is immovable or unstoppable.  ~ Guadalupe Guerra

The acceleration only happens WHILE there is a force.  Once the force stops, acceleration stops and the object will maintain a constant velocity until and unless another force acts on it.  For example, if we are in deep space and there is a stationary ball just sitting there, and you whack it with your hand, the force is only applied for a tiny fraction of a second, and in that tiny fraction of a second, the ball accelerated.  The moment your hand is no longer making contact with the ball, acceleration stops.  So the ball goes from 0 to whatever velocity in 0.05 seconds or however long your hand was in contact.

Let prove Keplers Law using Newtonian physics Basically keplers third law stare : r^3/T^2 = K where K is a constant. We know that objects orbiting the sun orbit in circular motion and that centripedal force is wholly supplied by gravity thus: Fc = Fg  we know Fc's magnitude is Fc = mv^2/r therefore GmM/r^2 = mv^2/r : where m = mass of the orbiter and M is the mass of thing the orbiter is orbiting GM/r^2 = v^2/r GM/r = v^2 we know v =(2 x pi x r) /T therefore GM/r = (4 x pi^2 x r^2)/T^2 T^2 x G x M = 4 x pi^2 x r^3  r^3 / T^2 = Gx M/(4 x pi^2) for a given object  like the sun or earth M is constant  therefore if we assume G X M/(4xpi^2) is constant and thus let it equal K r^3/T^2 = K hence we have proved keplers law!

+Cadwaladr Trajectory actually doesn't play into the acceleration in most cases, usually unless you have a large amount of air resistance. When you approximate projectile motion (something launched into the air), the vertical acceleration is controlled only by gravity (free fall) because air resistance for a lot of objects is negligible.  If you want to think about trajectory's effects on acceleration in cases where air resistance ISN'T negligible, consider factors that change air resistance by comparing objects that have vastly different velocities when dropped (why does a feather drop slowly and sometimes up a little?).

A law is essentially a mathematical equation which is consistent for various objects. For example, the calculation of gravitational force between you and an apple and the force between 2 planets use the same formula. Hence, the term law.

+Shangori Except laws aren't more reliable than theories. They're actually what makes up theories. Inside of one scientific theory, you have several scientific laws. We don't label a theory a theory until most of its assertions are verified as true, so one should never confuse scientific theories with the everyday meaning of that word.
Ghost7856  I think you should re-read my comment. You're making an assumption that doesn't apply here
Shangori But the word "instead" doesn't belong in this context, so your comment is poorly-worded either way.

Ghost7856 Really? I'm asking them to give an explanation why they're called laws instead of theories, for the people who don't understand the difference. You're the one that tries to see more into it then what I'm saying
Shangori Like I said, laws are part of theories. It's not one thing here and one thing there, even though laws can certainly be used on their own.

+Ghost7856  Nope, a law is independent of a theory and describes an experimental observation and allowing certain predictions about future behavior of nature, while a theory gives an explanation for it. Ideally it will make some predictions about behavior of nature, which can be used to falsify it. A law once establish will never change (unless the physics of nature changes), while a current theory might be substituted by a better one. Gravity is actually a good example. The "law" F =Gm1m2/r² will (under given circumstances and within set boundaries) hold true no matter what, while the theory leading to this law and explaining it is subject to change. past: Newton, masses attract, current: Einstein, matter bends space time, future: ???

Frank Schneider "while a theory gives an explanation for it" And therefore, the law is part of the theory. You may think otherwise, but Matthew O'Donnel disagrees with you, and I'd trust his words before yours all things considered.

If you'd have to throw general relativity out of the window tomorrow because it would have been falsified, you wouldn't have to toss out the law of gravity with it, as it would still hold true as you could easily observe from experiments. Ghost7856 A natural behavior (which is something mathematically described by a natural law) does not change, while a theory is a man-made mental construct, that continuously changes (which we call scientific progress). +Birgilios Marmaroglou He knew the distance between the Earth and Moon quite precisely - the ancient Greeks already knew it in terms of Earth's radius by looking at the time a full solar eclipse takes. In reality he probably deduced the form of the law of gravity by looking at Kepler's laws. If you assume that the orbits are circular, you can very easily derive that the 3rd law would be a consequence of a 1/r^2 force field. After that you just postulate your universal law of gravity and show that everything works out. It was more of guesswork, but most new science is, since the underlying principles of nature need to be axiomatized and are not derivable. The reason why his law takes precedence over, for instance, Kepler's laws is that it is significany more universal and has larger predictive power.

+Birgilios Marmaroglou It's pretty much impossible to tell exactly why Newton thought it was 1/r^2, because there are a multitude of reasons it could of been chosen by him that he could of understood at the time.  The two most likely are either  1) He believed Kepler's laws and after developing calculus managed to figure out that they require a force of 1/r^2 2) He realised from a very rudimentary intuitive understanding of field theory that a conservative force field spreading out over 3D drops of as 1/r^2, as it expands over distance like a sphere.  Though there's plenty of other explanations that could also be the case, that are less likely. Just guessing, trying lots of different ones, perhaps trying a summation of many ( or infinitely many ) forces of terms proportional to 1/r^n. From this trying to fit it to data to see which fits reality the best. Either doing this just by hand and slightly guessing, or perhaps he might of developed something along the lines of Taylor's expansion ( a way to expand out many terms which is commonly used in the modern day to approximate things) and found that the best fit for data was incredibly close to all terms other than 1/r^2 being 0.
